instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.3V3S5_EN: What is 3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi, I have a board with no power, Draws 16-17mA

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.6V
<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>:
 <SIGNAL>3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> =3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREF2</SIGNAL> = 2V
<SIGNAL>3V3S5_COMP2</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_VFB</SIGNAL> = 1.1V

It seems all the 3.3 Rails are coming up short, am I right?

threads.message: I did just try to plug in the bord again, and it’s constantly boot looping with the battery connected. The fans spin and goes from 15mA to 1Amp over and over.  This is without the side IO board plugged in. I don't have another known good battery to test, could it just be the battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
"all RTC signals"
Read the "How To collection" thread, for the future.
If board tries to start now, RTC signals should be good however.

You had missing <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> at <CHIP>U7930</CHIP> before; can you check it again now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Sorry, I just went in board view and measured anything that had RTC in it.
3v3sus is present when it tries to turn on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
All mentioned signals are steady high?
Be sure to test with original 85W Magsafe charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: It was the charger.. Thank you so much for your help, I feel so dumb lol.
